text: Hello everyone and welcome to our module on Bial.
Bial is a substance that is produced in the liver and then stored in the gallbladder,
and after a meal it is secreted into the duodenum to help us absorb fats.
It's made up mostly of water, but it also contains some phospholipids and electrolytes,
and from a physiology point of view the two most important components of bile are the
bile salts, which help to absorb lipids and bilirubin, and that's because bile is the
main mechanism by which bilirubin is excreted from the body.
I'll talk about bilirubin in a separate module, in this module today I'm going to focus
on bile in general and the bile salts.
So the reason we need bile salts in our bile is to help us absorb lipids, so let's talk
a little bit about the type of lipids you consume when you eat foods.
So on the screen here is the structure of a fatty acid.
It has a carboxylic acid group on the end and then a long chain of carbons and hydrogens.
Also on the screen here is a molecule of glycerol, and if you link three fatty acids to a
molecule of glycerol you will get a structure called a triglyceride, and this is what most
of the fats in our diet look like.
Most of the fats we consume are triglycerides, they are made up of a glycerol molecule here
attached to three different fatty acids.
The way we absorb the triglycerides that we consume in our meals into the bloodstream
is by breaking them down using an enzyme called pancreatic lipase, which is secreted by the
pancreas.
What pancreatic lipase does is it breaks down triglycerides into fatty acids and monoglycerides.
A monoglyceride is a glycerol molecule attached to only one fatty acid when it's attached
to three fatty acids it's called a triglyceride.
The problem with what I just showed you is that lipids are not soluble in water and there's
lots of water in our stomach and in our intestines.
So if not for the action of bile, what would happen when you consume a meal is that the
lipids and the water would separate like I've shown on the screen here.
Pancreatic lipase, which is water soluble, would then only be able to work at the interface
between the water and the lipids and it turns out this is a relatively small surface area.
So there wouldn't be much area in which for pancreatic lipase to work and as a result
fat digestion would be very inefficient.
Luckily we have bile salts and what bile salts do is they emulsify the lipids which means
they suspend them in the water and they do this by surrounding lipid particles and dissolving
them in water.
This makes much more surface area in which for pancreatic lipase to work and it helps
to aid in digestion.
If we zoom in on one of those suspended lipid particles on the last slide, what we would
see is that the bile salt is surrounding the lipid particles and it has two portions
of its molecule.
Each bile salt has a hydrophobic portion which like slippids and that will move towards
the inside, I've shown that in red here.
Each bile salt also has a hydrophilic portion of the molecule which likes water.
That's this blue portion right here.
So what bile salts do is they work as a bridge, part of the molecule binds to the lipids,
part of the molecule dissolves in water and therefore you can suspend lipids into droplets
to give more surface area for pancreatic lipase to work.
Substances that suspend lipids like this are called surfactants and you may know that soap
is also a surfactant.
If you have a greasy pan you're not going to be able to dissolve that grease in water
but if you add soap which is a surfactant, the soap will bind to the grease and it will
also dissolve in water and therefore you can get your pan to become clean.
So now let's talk about the chemical structure of bile salt so that we can understand why
they have one portion of their molecule that likes water and one portion of their molecule
that likes lipids so that they can function as surfactants.
Bile salts are synthesized from bile acids and two of the most common bile acids in the
human body are colic acid and Chenodioxy colic acid and I've shown their structure on the
screen here.
I've also shown the structure of cholesterol so you can see that the structure of these
bile acids is very similar to cholesterol and that can help to remind you that these
structures are synthesized from cholesterol in the liver.
To make bile acids into better surfactants they are conjugated to other structures which
means another structure is added to the molecule to create a hydrophilic end.
The two structures that are added are Taurine which is an organic acid.
This is a structure of Taurine on the screen here and glycine which you may know is an
amino acid and both of these are very hydrophilic and they are going to be added to this carboxylic
end of the bile acid molecule to create a bile salt.
Once we create a bile salt we now have a better surfactant because one end of the molecule
will be highly hydrophobic and it will like the lipids, one end will be highly hydrophilic
and it will like the water.
So I've shown this on the screen here.
If you take colic acid and you conjugate it to Taurine you get a substance called Tauric
Acid which is a bile salt.
It has one end which is hydrophobic made up of mostly carbons and hydrogens that have
shown in red here and it has another end which has the Taurine conjugated to it that is
very hydrophilic and will like water.
At the bottom of the screen I've shown what happens if you conjugate colic acid to glycine
you will create glycocolic acid.
It also has a very hydrophobic end which is shown in red here and it has a very hydrophilic
end shown in blue.
And if we go back to this slide here you can now hopefully understand from the chemical
structure how bile salts work as surfactant and now they have one end of the molecule that
likes the lipids and in other end that likes the water and therefore they can serve
as a bridge between the lipid and water environments and they can suspend those lipid molecules
in solution so that pancreatic lipase has more surface area in which to work for digestion.
So as we have seen in order to create bile salts which you need as surfactants for the
digestion of lipids you need to begin with bile acids and bile acids are synthesized
in the liver from cholesterol.
There are two synthesis pathways.
The classic pathway is the major pathway.
There is also a minor pathway called the acidic pathway.
The rate limiting enzyme for the classic pathway is 7 alpha hydroxylase.
It takes cholesterol molecules and adds a hydroxyl group to the 7 carbon hence the name 7 alpha
hydroxylase.
It creates a molecule called 7 alpha hydroxycholesterole.
There are then a series of steps in the liver which lead to the synthesis of bile acids
like colic acid.
7 alpha hydroxylase is a cytochrome P450 enzyme.
It also requires NADPH from the HMP shot.
It also requires oxygen to function.
Now let's talk about what happens to bile acids and bile salts once they reach the intestines.
They do not all pass out with the stool.
Some of them are reabsorbed.
This is called the enterohapatic circulation.
So most lipid absorption of triglycerides occurs in the jajunum but conjugated bile acids
are not absorbed with the lipids.
Pancreatic lipase releases the fatty acids and those get absorbed by aterocytes but the
bile salts remain behind.
They then pass to the distal small intestine and they're absorbed by active transporters
in the terminal ilium.
About 95% are absorbed and recycled and about 5% are excreted in this stool and as we
will discuss in a few slides this is a major way by which cholesterol is excreted from
the body.
This 5% that goes out of the stool comes from cholesterol and therefore this is a way
by which cholesterol is eliminated from the body.
So in most people think of bile salts they think of emulsification of fats.
That's because that's one of their main functions.
Don't forget there are two other functions of bile salts.
One is excretion of cholesterol as I just said and the third is as an antimicrobial.
So let's talk about cholesterol excretion in a little more detail.
Cholesterol is a lipid.
It's made up of mostly carbons and hydrogens as you can see on the screen here.
So it is not soluble in water in order to excrete it from the body therefore that means
you cannot use the urine.
What you can do is convert the cholesterol into a conjugated bile acid or a bile salt.
It then becomes water soluble and it can be excreted in the stool.
This is the main mechanism by which cholesterol is eliminated from the body.
There's a tie-in with pharmacology here.
There are very old rarely used cholesterol drugs that are called bile acid resins.
These are drugs like colostyramine and cholesterol and colcevillam.
These retain bile acids in the stool and prevent their resorption so that more bile acids
go out in the stool.
And when more bile acids like colic acid go out in the stool that means you are eliminating
more cholesterol from the body.
These drugs have largely been replaced by statins and other cholesterol drugs and they
have nasty side effects like bloating and diarrhea but a long time ago they were the only
drugs we had and they were used more often.
I talk about these in more detail in the modules on lipid drugs.
The third important function of bile salts is to serve as an antimicrobial.
The small intestine has relatively few bacteria especially compared to the colon.
And if you lose your bile salts what happens is bacterial overgrowth occurs and this is
sometimes seen in patients who have liver disease.
The mechanism by which bile salts prevent bacterial overgrowth is believed to be disruption
of bacterial cell membranes.
I've bolded that here because that's what you should remember for your boards.
There are other antibacterial effects that have been described as well.
What I'm going to talk about for the last few slides of this module is what happens if
you have disrupted bile flow to the intestines and that is called colostasis.
There are characteristic lab findings and symptoms of this disorder that you should know for
your boards and also for clinical medicines and they all make sense if you understand what
bile does.
The lab findings of a patient who has disrupted bile flow to the intestines will include hyperbilly
rubinemia that should make sense to you because as I told you at the beginning of this module
Billy Rubin is one of the main components of bile.
The type of hyperbilly rubinemia is a direct or conjugated hyperbilly rubinemia and in the
Billy Rubin Module I talk more about why it's a direct hyperbilly rubinemia when you have
colostasis.
Another characteristic finding is elevated alkaline phosphatase.
Acid phosphatase is synthesized by bile duct epithelial cells and when there is obstruction
to bile flow the level of this enzyme in the serum will rise.
The symptoms of colostasis include jaundice which is yelling at the skin.
This happens when the Billy Rubin level is high.
There is also paritis.
This is itching and this is believed to occur because bile salts deposit in the skin.
You can also sometimes see dark urine.
If you have elevated conjugated Billy Rubin levels the urine will turn dark.
I talk more about this in the Billy Rubin Module.
And then finally you can have clay colored stools.
That's because Billy Rubin is converted to stercobillin in the intestines and that's
what makes your stool dark.
If you lose bile and therefore lose Billy Rubin flow to the intestines you will get clay
colored pale stools.
Long term if you have obstruction to bile flow you can see fat malabsorption and loss
of fat soluble vitamins and this should make sense to you based on what we've been discussing
because those bile salts are essential for a multiplication of fats and their absorption.
To understand how we make a diagnosis from lab tests of bile obstruction or holy stasis
you need to understand the enzyme alkaline phosphatase which most people call alkyphosph.
This enzyme is produced by bile duct and pathelial cells and when there is obstruction of bile
flow these cells will increase their alkaline phosphatase synthesis.
The mechanism is not completely understood but what you will see clinically is that plasma
levels of alkaline phosphatase will rise when there is an obstruction to bile flow.
Now hepatocytes contain the enzymes AST and ALT.
I talk more about these in the liver modules and when you have damage to the hepatocytes
you can see a rise in the serum levels of AST and ALT.
Which you need to understand is that when there is holy stasis the primary problem is with
the bile duct and pathelial cells.
So you will see an increase in alkaline phosphatase that is much much greater than the increase
in AST and ALT that may result from damage to hepatocytes.
This is because the primary site of dysfunction is in the bile ducts.
There is some secondary effect on the pathocytes but it is not as great.
Therefore the rise in ALT and ALT is much smaller than the rise in alkyphosph.
To understand this let's look at this picture.
So let's imagine we have a big gallstone lodged in the common bile duct right here or maybe
it's a tumor at the head of the pancreas.
This will obviously obstruct the bile flow from the liver into the intestines.
As a result these bile ducts will become very dilated and the bile duct of the ethereal
cells will create lots of alkyphosph.
So you will see a very high level of alkaline phosphatase in the serum if you measure it.
Now that back up of the bile flow all the way to the liver will cause some effect and some
damage of liver cells up here.
So you will see a rise in the AST and the ALT levels but that rise in the AST and the
ALT levels will not be as high as the rise in the alkyphosph.
You will see a much greater rise in alkyphosph than you do in AST and ALT when you have a
colystatic problem or an obstruction to bile flow and it's very important that you understand
that.
Contrast that pattern that I just showed you with the hepatocellular pattern of liver
damage.
This occurs when the primary site of dysfunction from pathology is with the hepatocytes
in the liver.
In this case you will see a rise in the AST and ALT levels in the serum that is much
greater than the rise in alkaline phosphatase.
The rise in alkaline phosphatase occurs because there's some secondary effect on the bile
ducts but the primary problem lies with the liver cells.
And this is the form of liver function test abnormality that is seen in many forms of
liver disease.
To understand this let's imagine we have some pathologic process that's damaging the
liver here.
This will cause the AST and ALT levels to rise significantly.
But remember there are bile ducts inside the liver so you will have some secondary effect
on the bile duct and pathelial cells so you will see some rise in alkaline phosphatase
but the rise in alkaline phosphatase will be relatively small compared to the larger
rise in AST and ALT.
So I've summarized on the screen here the two characteristic patterns of bile and liver
damage and it's very important that you understand these two patterns for step one of your
boards and also for clinical medicine.
We often look at the alkyphosph levels and the AST and ALT levels and we use those levels
to try and determine whether the patient's problem lies in the liver or in the bile ducts.
When the alkyphosph rise is much greater than the rise in AST and ALT then the primary
abnormality relates to the bile ducts.
This is called the colytatic pattern because this is what occurs when there's obstruction
to bile flow which is called colytasis.
When the rise in AST or ALT is much greater than the rise in alkaline phosphatase then the
primary abnormality relates to hepatocytes.
This is called the hepatocellular pattern of liver damage.
So on the screen here I've put two specific examples with actual numbers to help you understand.
So a normal AST and ALT is about 50 and a normal alkyphosph is about 100.
The actual normals are slightly different than that but that's an easy way to remember
it when you're looking at board questions.
So in example number one we have an AST that is 100 and an ALT that is 120.
So these two values are about twice the normal level.
Then we have an alkyphosph level that is 500 so this alkyphosph level is about five times
the normal level.
So we have a rise in alkyphosph that is much much greater than the rise in AST and ALT
and this is a type of pattern you would see with someone who has colytasis for example
if they have a Gulfstone lives in their common bile duct.
In example two we have an AST of 500 and ALT of 550 so these are both about 10 times
the upper limit of normal for AST and ALT.
Our alkyphosph on the other hand is 200 so this is only about two times the upper limit
of normal.
So we have a rise in AST and ALT that is much greater than the rise in alkyphosph.
This is the hepatocellular pattern of liver damage and this is a type of pattern you would
see in a patient as a primary liver disorder.
Once you identify the colytstatic pattern of liver function test abnormalities once
you identify colytasis the best first test after that is an imaging test of the bile
ducts.
Usually it is a right upper quadrant ultrasound.
That is because this will tell you whether the bile ducts are dilated or normal and
this will differentiate extra hepatic causes of colytasis from intra hepatic causes of
colytasis.
To understand this let us go back to our drawing here.
If we have a Gulfstone lodged in the common bile duct we will get very large bile ducts.
They will become dilated and distended.
You can see this on imaging.
On the other hand there are intra hepatic causes of bile flow obstruction.
There are processes that primarily affect the bile ducts in the liver here.
They can obstruct bile flow inside the liver.
If one of those processes is occurring then the bile ducts will be normal and you know
that you need to look in the liver to find the source of biliari obstruction.
So if your imaging study shows dilated bile ducts then you have an extra hepatic cause
of colytasis and this includes things like gallstones, pancreatic masses or biliari structures.
To work up of a patient with an extra hepatic cause of colytasis usually involves imaging.
You are going to try to image the gallstone or the pancreatic mass or the strictures to
determine the best treatment for that problem.
If your imaging study shows normal bile ducts then you have an intra hepatic cause of colytasis
and the work up of these disorders usually involves lab tests or a biopsia of the liver.
Some of the things that can cause intra hepatic colytasis include primary biliari cirrhosis
which is a disorder I discuss in its own module.
There is a characteristic colytasis that often occurs in pregnancy that is intra hepatic
or all contraceptives sometimes cause patients to have an intra hepatic colytatic problem.
The estrogen can lead to obstruction of bile flow and then finally erythromycin is a
well described cause of intra hepatic colytasis.
A small number of patients develop this problem when they take erythromycin.
There are numerous other causes of intra hepatic colytasis but all of these would have normal
bile duct imaging on your right of a quadrant ultrasound.
That's why the imaging of the bile ducts is the best first test once you identify colytasis
and that concludes our module on bile.
Hi everybody and welcome to our module on gastrointestinal embryology.
Let's begin by going back to a point very early on in development.
Just a few weeks after fertilization the embryo looks something like this drawing on the
left.
There are two cavities, one's called the yoke sac and one's called the amniotic cavity
and where they meet this is called the embryonic disc and this is where all the action is in
the growth of a human being.
This is where all the organs and structures that we know are going to come from.
What happens early on in development is that this embryonic cavity folds in multiple directions.
It folds in this direction, it also folds in the direction coming in and out of the screen.
So it folds in four directions and wraps around the yoke sac and after a few weeks you then
have something that looks like the drawing on the right side of the screen.
You can see this blue line that was the interior of the amniotic cavity is now stretching
all the way around the growing embryo.
What you have in the middle of the screen is a white area which used to be the yoke sac
and this is now a hollow tube and that is going to grow into the digestive tract that
is called the digestive tube and it comes from the yoke sac.
This picture on the left shows a zoomed in view of the embryonic disc.
Remember that's the interface between the amniotic cavity and the yoke sac that's where
all the action takes place and where all the organs we know in the adult are going to
come from.
If you zoom in on that embryonic disc you will see that it's made up of three layers.
The middle layer shown in red is called the misoderm.
One of the outer layers is called the ectoderm that's shown in pink.
The other outer layer is called the endoderm that's shown in brown.
As this early structure develops into the structure on the right side of the screen you
will see that once again there is a hollow tube that comes from the yoke sac shown here
that's going to develop into the digestive tract and you can see in this picture on the
right that it's surrounded by brown.
I show you that to remind you that the surrounding structures of the GI tube come from the endoderm.
Things like the lining of the GI tract and many of the abdominal organs all come from
the endoderm which wraps around this digestive tube which came from the yoke sac.
Just outside of that endoderm you can see red and that red represents misoderm and that's
where all the connective tissue and muscles surrounding abdominal structures in the GI
tract are going to come from.
Here's a summary slide just to make these points clear.
The endoderm develops into the GI tract.
It forms the GI tract epithelium and the glands, many organs bud off from this including
the liver, pancreas and trachea.
We'll talk about all of this in this module today.
The misoderm forms the surrounding structures, things like the stroma, the GI tract connective
tissues, muscles, peritoneum.
The spleen is a special organ in the abdomen because it comes from misoderm.
We'll talk about this later.
Most of the abdominal organs come from endoderm.
The spleen is unique and that it comes from misoderm.
As the embryo continues to develop it eventually will start to look like this.
At this point we have a long gut tube.
This portion up here is going to form the mouth and the farranx.
These are the fringial pouches.
Then the remaining length of the developing digestive tube can be split up into three sections.
The first section is called the foregut.
The next one is the midgut and the last one is the hindgut.
What's important to know about these three sections in the developing embryo is that each
one will eventually be supplied by a different branch of the abdominal aorta.
All the structures that derive from the foregut will be supplied by the siliac trunk.
That includes the esophagus and the stomach which is biting out here and other structures.
The midgut will all be supplied by the SMA and the hindgut will all be supplied by the inferior
mesenteric artery.
At this stage the entire yokesack has mostly been converted into the digestive tube except
for this little portion out here which is called the vitylene duct.
This will eventually disappear but as we'll talk about later there are some disorders where
it persists into the newborn baby and this can cause some congenital anomalies.
This slide summarizes the different portions of the GI tract and where they derive from
in the developing embryo.
The foregut gives rise to everything supplied by the siliac trunk and that's all the structures
from the mouth to the ampula of vatter.
The midgut gives rise to everything supplied by the superior mesenteric artery or SMA.
This is everything from the ampula vatter to the transverse colon and finally the hindgut
gives rise to everything supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery that includes structures
from the transverse colon to the rectum.
Next let's talk about the mesenteri.
When you look inside the abdominal cavity you can find sheets of connected tissue called
mesenteri.
Mesenteri is made up of a double layer of peritoneal tissue and it suspends the abdominal organs
from cavity walls.
Blood vessels also travel through the mesenteri as they go from the aorta to the organs which
they supply with blood.
Organes that we call intraperitoneal are entirely enclosed and wrapped with mesenteri.
I'll show you a picture of that in a minute.
Organes that we call retroperitoneal are covered by peritoneum only on their anterior wall
and then they lie against the posterior abdominal wall.
Here's a recreation of some structures in the abdomen to give you an idea of what I'm
talking about.
The red line here represents the mesenteri and you can see that there's a loop of small
intestine here completely wrapped in mesenteri so that would be an intraperitoneal structure.
Other structures in the back of the abdomen like the aorta and the inferior vina cava
are not wrapped in mesenteri.
They are retroperitoneal structures.
They have mesenteri covering only their anterior wall.
As we talked about earlier in this module, connective tissue structures in the abdomen
do not derive from endoderm.
They come from the mesoderm.
The entire mesenteri comes from the mesoderm and that's easy to remember because it has
the word mes in the name of the structure.
There are two types of mesenteri that form in the fetus.
The first type is towards the back of the fetus that's called dorsal mesenteri.
Dorsal means towards the back and the second type is towards the front that's called ventral
mesenteri.
Ventral means towards the front.
Most of the connective tissue structures in the abdomen come from dorsal mesenteri.
The reason for this is because the gut moves away from the posterior wall in development
and the dorsal mesenteri grows between the gut and posterior wall so that most structures
are covered by this mesenteri.
To understand this better, imagine that we have the posterior wall of the fetus and we have
the gut tube here.
It is going to be covered in mesenteri and then it is going to migrate away from that
posterior wall.
As it does so, it will pull that mesenteri with it and the result will be that this dorsal
mesenteri coming off the back of the fetus ends up covering most structures in the abdomen
and being responsible for most of the mesenteri in the abdomen.
Ventral mesenteri on the other hand only exists in a couple of places.
You can find it in the esophagus.
You can also find it in the stomach.
That's one of the most important places.
We'll talk about that in a second and you can find it in the upper duodenum.
It is derived from a structure called the septum transversum which is mesenchym tissue
that also comes from the mesoderm.
What's important to know about the ventral mesenteri is that the liver grows into this and thus two
structures on either side of the liver come from the ventral mesenteri.
The first one is the laceromentum and the second one is the falciforum ligament.
This is an image depicting the septum transversum and remember all the ventral mesenteri comes
from the septum transversum.
You can see that it's a sheet of tissue going across the liver to the stomach and the
liver is growing into it.
This means that when the baby is fully formed all that will remain of the septum transversum
and the ventral mesenteri will be this connection between the liver and the anterior abdominal
wall and that's called the falciforum ligament and the connection between the liver and the
stomach and that is called the laceromentum.
Here's another picture of the liver and stomach.
You can see the laceromentum is this structure in here between the stomach and the liver.
What's shown is the falciforum ligament which is on the outside of the liver and connects
to the anterior abdominal wall.
Both of those structures derive from ventral mesenteri.
The mesenteri goes by different names depending upon which abdominal organ it is surrounding.
So the mesenteri around the stomach is called mesogastrium.
The mesenteri around the duodenum is mesododinum and around the colon is mesocolon.
Hopefully you all get to go into the anatomy lab and open up the abdomen and when you do
you will see that there is this sheet of connective and fatty tissue hanging off the stomach
and that is called the greater omentum.
The word omentum is a Latin word for apron and the greater omentum hangs from the greater
curvature of the stomach and covers the intestines.
It is derived from mesogastrium and therefore derived from mesoderm tissue.
There's also the laceromentum which we saw on the last slide.
That is a connection between the stomach and liver and as I said before it's high yield
to remember that that structure is formed from ventral mesenteri.
If we go back to this picture here this is the greater curvature of the stomach and this
is the greater omentum hanging off of it.
If you go into the anatomy lab you will see that it literally looks like an apron that
hangs off the stomach and covers the intestines.
This is the lesser curvature of the stomach and this is the lesser omentum which is a much
smaller structure than the greater omentum.
Now what I'm going to do is talk about each of the three sections of the embryonic gut
tube, the foregut, the midgut and the hindgut and I'll talk about how each section develops
and the important anomalies that you need to know about for step one.
We'll start by talking about the foregut.
This is what forms the esophagus and the stomach and the most important thing to know
about the foregut is that the lung will bud off from the esophagus in the developing embryo.
This budding off of the lung is called the respiratory diverticulum or the lung bud.
Eventually a structure called the tracheo esophageal septum will form and it will divide the respiratory
diverticulum or the lung bud from the esophagus and then the fetus will go on to mature and
develop a separate trachea and esophagus.
If there is abnormal development of this tracheo esophageal septum, that leads to congenital
pathology and the most important pathology to know about is esophageal atreja.
This is a closed esophagus and this is what occurs when the septum deviates posteriorly.
If we go back to this picture shown right here is the lung budding off from the esophagus
and a septum needs to form between the lung and the esophagus to divide the two tubes
into separate structures.
If this septum deviates posteriorly it will cut off the esophagus and then the esophagus
will end in a blind tube and that's called esophageal atreja.
There are three forms of esophageal atreja.
The most common form is called esophageal atreja that's EA with a tracheo esophageal
fisture.
A tracheo esophageal fisture is a connection between the trachea which is here in the
lungs and the esophagus which is this distal portion of the esophagus.
The proximal portion of the esophagus has been cut off.
That's what's called esophageal atreja.
Another form of esophageal atreja which is less common is called pure esophageal atreja.
This is where the esophagus ends in a blind tube and the more distal esophagus is not
connected to the trachea at all.
Then finally there's a more rare H type where the esophagus and the trachea are both
separate tubes but they are connected by a fistula.
When the fetus develops esophageal atreja the esophagus does not connect to the stomach
as we have just seen.
This means the baby cannot swallow amniotic fluid.
This means there will be an excess of amniotic fluid present in the mother and that is called
polyhydramdeos.
When these children are born they will have drooling and choking and vomiting and all
of this is because accumulation of secretions is occurring in their mouth because they cannot
swallow those secretions and pass them into their stomach and intestines.
To try and control the excess secretions a nasogastric tube is often passed into the
stomach of babies who have symptoms like this but in the case of esophageal atreja you
will find that you cannot pass the angitube into the stomach and that is because the esophagus
ends in a blind pouch and this is a characteristic finding of babies with esophageal atreja.
If there is a fistula between the esophagus and the trachea as we saw in some forms of
esophageal atreja the baby will develop gastric distension and that is because air is passing
from the trachea into the stomach and you can see an excess of air in the stomach on
a chest X-ray of these children.
In addition these babies will have reflux of stomach contents and they will develop aspiration
pneumonia and this will lead to respiratory distress.
The treatment of esophageal atreja is a surgical repair and the prognosis is generally okay.
Sometimes there is residual dysmotility and swallowing problems in the esophagus and
these children often suffer from heartburn or gastroesophageal reflux disease as a result
of damage that occurred to the esophagus.
Next let's talk about development of the midgut and there are two phenomena that occur
in midgut development that you need to know about.
The first one is called herniation and the second one is called rotation.
Herniation is where the contents of the midgut normally exit the abdomen and then return.
This is a normal part of development.
Rotation is when the contents of the midgut rotate around the superior mesenteric arteries.
We'll talk about both of these now and we'll start with herniation.
About the six week of development the abdomen temporarily becomes too small so the midgut
herniates through the umbilical cord and I've bolded the words through the umbilical cord

Coli Stasis is the lack of bile flow and if bile can't flow into the duodenum, then
you cannot excrete Billy-Rubin.
This can occur because of extra hepatic obstruction like a gallstone or a pancreatic mass.
There are also some intra hepatic causes of coli stasis.
Disease processes like alcoholic liver disease or viral hepatitis tend to clog up the
intra hepatic bile ducts and they can also lead to coli stasis.
In coli stasis, conjugation occurs normally but excretion is impaired.
Therefore you see a rise in the direct or conjugated Billy-Rubin level.
This is in stark contrast to hemolysis where it was the indirect or uncongiated Billy-Rubin
level that began to become elevated.
Besides an elevated direct Billy-Rubin level, some other findings that can help you identify
Billy-ary obstruction include a coli static liver function test pattern.
I talk about this in more detail in the bile module but this occurs with a very marked
increase in alkyphosph, a much greater increase in the alkyphosph level than the increase
in ALT and AST levels.
And in another finding you can see in Billy-ary obstruction is clay-colored stools.
You lack stercoblin in a Billy-ary obstruction.
Therefore the stools will be clay-colored or pale because recall as I told you before,
stercoblin is what gives your stools their dark brown color.
What you will see in the urine in cases of Billy-ary obstruction is dark urine.
That's because we have an elevated serum level of conjugated Billy-Rubin and conjugated
Billy-Rubin is water soluble.
Therefore it will cross the glomerulus, spill into the urine and make the urine dark.
In addition you will see absent urobulinogen.
That's because no Billy-Rubin is making it to the intestine in Billy-ary obstruction.
Therefore there's a loss of formation of urobulinogen.
If we go back to our overview slide here, what's happening in Billy-ary obstruction is that
conjugated Billy-Rubin is being formed but it cannot make it out into the intestine.
Therefore it is spilling into the serum to give you a high level of conjugated Billy-Rubin.
This is water soluble so it can cross into the urine to give you dark urine.
In addition, because you do not have Billy-Rubin flowing through the intestines, you lose your
stercopillin and your stool becomes pale.
It cannot become dark brown because it doesn't have stercopillin.
The third general cause of hyperbilly-Rubinemia is a primary liver disorder and this is one
of the more frustrating causes to understand as a student.
It would be nice if liver disease caused a direct or indirect hyperbilly-Rubinemia but
it doesn't.
It often gives a mixed increase of both direct and indirect Billy-Rubin levels.
Billy-Rubin fractionation is unreliable for diagnosing liver disease as a cause of hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
The usual finding is an elevated total Billy-Rubin level that is increased with a mixed increase
of the two fractionated forms of Billy-Rubin.
When patients have primary liver disease, you are not going to make the diagnosis by looking
at the Billy-Rubin abnormality, which you're going to do instead is look at the liver function tests,
antibody tests imaging or a biopsy.
The Billy-Rubin fractionation is unhelpful.
Some primary liver diseases give an unconjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
This occurs in liver diseases where there's lots of a patocyte damage.
If you damage the patocyte so much that they can't conjugate Billy-Rubin anymore, then
you will see a rise in the unconjugated Billy-Rubin level.
This happens in patients who have chronic hepatitis or advanced cirrhosis.
Basically, they have fried their liver so much that it cannot carry out the conjugation
function any longer.
Other liver disorders cause a conjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
This occurs when liver disease leads to intra-hepatic colystasis.
Some liver diseases have prominent damage to the bile ducts and they plug up the bile
ducts inside of the liver.
You can see this in viral hepatitis and alcoholic hepatitis and non-alcoholic stato hepatitis.
In reality, many liver diseases have elements of both hepatocyte and intra-hepatic bile
duct involvement.
This is why fractionating the Billy-Rubin into direct and indirect is not helpful for
making a diagnosis of a primary liver disease as the cause of hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
Euro-Bullinogen levels in the urine are also variable and unpredictable in primary liver
disease problems.
Early in liver disease, you can see an increase in the Euro-Bullinogen in the urine.
That's because Euro-Bullinogen is absorbed from the intestines as usual, but it's not
being properly excreted in the bile, therefore it spills into the urine and raises the
Euro-Bullinogen level.
Late in liver disease, you can see a lack of conjugated Billy-Rubin going to the intestines
and this leads to less formation of Euro-Bullinogen and therefore less Euro-Bullinogen in the
urine.
So for this reason, it's very difficult to predict that for a patient with a given liver
disease, what will happen to their Euro-Bullinogen level in the urine?
This slide shows a table as you can find in many textbooks in board review books listing
the lab findings associated with hyperbilly-Rubinemia of different causes.
When hemolysis is the cause of hyperbilly-Rubinemia, the hallmark is an indirect hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
The urine-billy-Rubin level will be normal, meaning none will be detected and the Euro-Bullinogen
level will be increased as I described previously.
When there is Billy-Rubinemia obstruction, the hallmark is a rise in the direct Billy-Rubin
level.
Direct Billy-Rubin is water soluble, so it will cross into the urine.
You will see an increased level of urine-billy-Rubin, meaning the urine will turn dark and you will
see an absence of Euro-Bullinogen in the urine.
And then as I just described in primary liver disease, the elevation of Billy-Rubin is usually
of a mixed type, both indirect and direct.
The urine-billy-Rubin is usually increased because there is usually some direct Billy-Rubin
rise in the serum and the Euro-Bullinogen level is variable depending on whether it is
early or late in the course of liver disease.
So hemolysis-billy-ary obstruction and liver disease are the three major causes of hyperbilly-Rubinemia,
but there are some more rare special causes and you need to know these especially for step
one, so we'll go through all the causes listed on the slide in the remainder of this module.
The famine is an antibiotic that is sometimes used to treat tuberculosis and prebenicid
is a drug that can be used to treat gout.
And both of these drugs have hyperbilly-Rubinemia as a well-described side effect that occurs
at a small number of patients.
Both of these medicines can compete with Billy-Rubin for uptake by the liver, so therefore they
can blunt the liver's uptake of unconjugated Billy-Rubin and they can cause a mild increase
in the unconjugated Billy-Rubin level and also of course the total Billy-Rubin level.
Importantly all the other liver function tests will be normal and when patients present
a clinic with a rise in the Billy-Rubin level looking at the med list for one of these
drugs is one of the first things that's usually done.
Gilberre syndrome occurs when patients have decreased function of the UDP glucuroneal
transphase or the UGT enzyme inside of their hepatocytes.
Recall that this enzyme conjugates glucuronic acid to Billy-Rubin so that Billy-Rubin will
become water soluble and can be excreted in the bile.
If we go back a few slides this is the UDP glucuroneal transphase enzyme.
It takes unconjugated Billy-Rubin and adds molecules of glucuronic acid so that conjugated
Billy-Rubin like Billy-Rubin die glucuroneid will be synthesized and this structure is
much more water soluble and can go out in the bile.
One of the common reasons why patients with Gilberre syndrome have decreased function
of this enzyme is because they have a defective promoter of the UGT gene.
As a result they synthesize less UGT enzyme than is normal and they have a mildly decreased
level of enzymes inside of their hepatocytes.
Clinically the findings in Gilberre syndrome include a mild increase in total and unconjugated
Billy-Rubin levels.
Usually the level remains less than three and remember what I told you before it has
to be higher than three to cause jaundice.
So usually these patients are not walking around with jaundice however if you measure
the serum Billy-Rubin level you will find that it's mildly elevated.
Patients with Gilberre syndrome can get jaundice however if something occurs to increase their
Billy-Rubin production.
Remember they are deficient in the enzyme that conjugates Billy-Rubin so if Billy-Rubin
production goes up then the Billy-Rubin level can get high and they can get jaundice.
Things that increase Billy-Rubin production include fasting, febrile illnesses, heavy
physical exertion, stress and mences, the mechanism by which these things cause and rise
and Billy-Rubin production is not well understood.
But in all of us these activities can raise Billy-Rubin production.
If our UDP, Glucurin-L Transferase enzymes are normal that's no problem.
They can metabolize the extra Billy-Rubin but in patients with Gilberre syndrome they
can metabolize it and they can develop jaundice in the setting of these items that are listed
on the screen.
Other than occasionally developing jaundice there are no serious clinical consequences
and Gilberre syndrome is generally a mild disease.
It's often picked up incidentally when patients come in for annual physical and primary
care doctor measures their Billy-Rubin level.
Crigler Nejar syndrome is like a severe version of Gilberre syndrome.
These born with this condition have severely reduced or absent UGT enzyme levels inside
of their liver cells.
As a result these babies are unable to conjugate Billy-Rubin effectively.
The more severe type is called type 1 this usually presents in infancy.
These babies have very high levels of unconjugated Billy-Rubin, often greater than 20.
They have jaundice that is obvious from looking at their skin and they often die from Billy-Rubin-induced
brain damage which is called connectors.
We'll talk about that in a minute.
This is often a fatal condition and these babies usually don't survive.
To understand connectors you need to recall that unconjugated Billy-Rubin is soluble in
fats and lipids.
Therefore it easily crosses the blood-brain barrier.
It can also enter the placenta if the mother has high levels of Billy-Rubin in her serum.
This means that unconjugated Billy-Rubin can act as a neurotoxin.
It can poison the basal gangria and the brainstem nuclei and this can be fatal for children
with high Billy-Rubin levels.
You usually need a very high Billy-Rubin level to develop connectors.
Billy needs to be greater than 25 but like I told you on the last slide, type 1,
Crigular Najar often creates Billy-Rubin levels that are higher than 25 and it often creates
unconjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
That's why babies with Crigular Najar can die from connectorous.
Newborn babies especially preterm babies are particularly vulnerable and we'll talk
about in a few slides how neonatal jaundice is a risk factor for connectorous for newborn
and preterm babies.
There is a type 2 Crigular Najar syndrome which is less severe.
The Billy-Rubin level is less than 20 and babies born with this variant of the syndrome
have a reduced risk of neurologic consequences.
What you need to know about this type 2 syndrome which is very rare for step 1 is that it's
sometimes treated with two drugs, phenobarbital and chlephibrate.
Phenobarbital is a seizure drug or a sedative and chlephibrate is a lipid lowering agent.
So why would you give these two drugs to a baby with Crigular Najar?
Well it turns out that through mechanisms that aren't completely understood both of these
drugs can induce gluteuronidation in the liver.
They can cause more Billy-Rubin to become conjugated.
Therefore they can lower the Billy-Rubin levels by up to 25%.
Now in patients with a severe form of Crigular Najar that's not going to help.
Even knocking the level down 25% usually doesn't help.
But in children with this type 2 less severe form if you can knock the Billy-Rubin level
down 25%, you can prevent a lot of the neurologic complications and therefore these two drugs
are sometimes administered to children with this variant of Crigular Najar.
Dubin Johnson syndrome causes a conjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia and this makes it distinct from
Gilberre syndrome and Crigular Najar syndrome.
Both of those conditions cause an un-conjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
The cause of elevated Billy-Rubin levels in Dubin Johnson syndrome is defective liver
excretion of conjugated Billy-Rubin patients with Dubin Johnson have abnormal genes that
code for substances called multi-drug resistance proteins.
They get these names because they play an important role in resistance to chemotherapy
drugs.
But in the case of Dubin Johnson syndrome, the multi-drug resistance proteins are necessary
for Billy-Rubin excretion into the bile and if they are abnormal the patient will be
unable to effectively excrete Billy-Rubin in the bile.
Therefore, there will be a conjugated hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
The clinical findings therefore of Dubin Johnson syndrome include obviously an increase in
conjugated Billy-Rubin.
The total Billy-Rubin level is usually in the 2-5 range, not that high and at least half
of it or so will be conjugated.
Because conjugated Billy-Rubin is soluble in water, you may see Billy-Rubin in the urine.
You won't see that in Gilberre syndrome or Kirklander jar because the un-conjugated
Billy-Rubin is not water soluble.
There's usually no puritis in this syndrome and why is that important?
Well if you have Billy-ary obstruction, you can also see a rise in the conjugated Billy-Rubin
level.
But in Billy-ary obstruction, you also cannot excrete bile salts and the bile
salts deposit in the skin and cause puritis.
But in Dubin Johnson syndrome, there's no puritis because Billy-ary obstruction are being
excreted as normal.
One of the key features of this syndrome to know about is that the liver turns black.
And a classic description of a patient with Dubin Johnson syndrome is someone who goes
in for abdominal surgery unrelated to the liver.
Maybe it's for appendicitis or gallbladder surgery.
And the surgeon notes that the liver is black.
That patient has Dubin Johnson syndrome and it's relatively mild and they haven't been
aware of it their whole life.
It's being detected now at abdominal surgery when the surgeon looks at their liver.
In general, Dubin Johnson syndrome is a benign condition and no treatment is required.
You can think of it as the equivalent of Gilberra syndrome except that it causes conjugated
hyperbilly-rubinemia instead of un-conjugated hyperbilly-rubinemia.
Rotor syndrome is very similar to Dubin Johnson.
These patients also have an increase in conjugated Billy-Rubin.
However, it's a milder increase and they don't have a black liver.
That's what differentiates it from Dubin Johnson.
And I showed you a normal colored liver here just to remind you that rotors syndrome
is different from Dubin Johnson only in that it does not cause the black liver.
Newborn babies can develop jaundice that is called neonatal jaundice and there are several
mechanisms by which the Billy-Rubin level and newborn babies can become elevated.
The first is that these babies just have high Billy-Rubin levels because they have more
red blood cells with a shorter lifespan so there is more turnover of heme and therefore
increase Billy-Rubin levels in general.
In addition, the UDP glucurineal transphorase enzyme takes several weeks to mature.
When babies are born it is immature so it is not able to metabolize Billy-Rubin as effectively
as it will when the baby gets a little bit older.
It takes about 14 weeks for the enzyme to reach its adult level of functioning.
As a result, newborn babies often have an increased level of un-conjugated Billy-Rubin.
They are producing more Billy-Rubin and they are less able to metabolize it.
If this is severe, it can lead to connectors and preterm infants are at the greatest risk.
Because they have very immature UDP glucurineal transphorase enzymes, therefore they are not
able to metabolize Billy-Rubin very well and they can get very high Billy-Rubin levels.
Luckily newborn babies with elevated Billy-Rubin levels are identified and there is a very
effective treatment and that is phototherapy.
This involves exposing the newborn baby's skin to light of a specific wavelength.
This is a picture of a newborn baby undergoing phototherapy.
So why does it help to expose their skin to light of a specific wavelength?
Well it turns out that light can convert Billy-Rubin into a substance called lumi-Rubin.
This is an isomerization of Billy-Rubin.
It converts it to something with the same chemical formula but a different structure.
And that different structure is lumi-Rubin and it is more water soluble.
This allows for excretion of Billy-Rubin without conjugation.
And newborn babies who have neonatal jaundice will have to stay in the hospital for a few days or
sometimes a few weeks under the lamp like this baby here until their Billy-Rubin level falls to normal
and their liver is able to conjugate normally.
For the final slide in this module I'm going to give you my Billy-Rubin algorithm for tackling
problems of hyperbilly-Rubinemia.
When you're faced with a patient who has hyperbilly-Rubinemia either in a board question
or clinically the first thing you want to do is ask yourself is the elevation in Billy-Rubin
isolated meaning is it occurring by itself or is it occurring in association with other
liver function test abnormalities?
If the hyperbilly-Rubinemia is not isolated then you want to look at the other LFTs like
AST and ALT and alkaline phosphatase.
If you see an increase in AST and ALT that is much greater than the rise in alkaline
phosphatase that is called the a patocellular pattern of liver function test abnormalities.
I discussed this in more detail in the module on bile but this pattern of LFT abnormalities
occurs in many liver diseases.
On the other hand if the alkaline phosphatase is increased to a much greater degree than
the AST and ALT that is called the cholestatic pattern of liver function test abnormalities
and that is what you see when you have cholestasis or obstruction of bile flow as can occur
in gallstones and pancreatic masses.
But the point here is that when the Billy-Rubin level is increased in association with other
abnormalities you want to focus on the other liver function test in order to make the diagnosis.
On the other hand if you have an isolated hyperbilly-Rubinemia in the setting of normal liver
function test then there is only a small group of disorders that can cause this.
Clinically one of the most common causes of this problem is hemolysis.
For your board you want to consider more rare conditions.
If you have an isolated direct hyperbilly-Rubinemia that could be due to dubin-Johnson syndrome
or rotors syndrome.
If you have an isolated indirect hyperbilly-Rubinemia that can be due to drugs as we discussed.
Also Gilberra syndrome, Kriggle and Ajara syndrome and you can also see this in neonatal
jaundice.
But the point here is that the first thing you want to do is decide whether or not the
Billy-Rubin elevation is isolated or not and based on that it becomes relatively straight
forward to work out the cause.
And that concludes our module on Billy-Rubin.
